subject: Re: [junit] Is it really neccessery to use Junit with some kind of IDE ?
msgSnippet: ... Again, I speak of the full unit test suite being run outside of the IDE. When developing within an IDE by all means use the IDE s unit test facilities for
messageBody:
On 12/8/05, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On 12/8/05, Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > > The two are not mutually exclusive.
> > >
> > > Everybody around me uses an IDE and while they are doing development,
> > they
> > > build everything inside the IDE and when they are ready to check in,
> > they
> > > move to the shell/command prompt and build with ant to make sure they
> > are
> > > not breaking anything.
> > >
> > > I *strongly* recommend using an IDE, and not just for JUnit. Maybe you
> > > think you are productive with your current text editor (emacs, vi,
> > TextEdit,
> > > etc...) but I guarantee that your productivity will shoot up with an
> > IDE.
> >
> > I wasn't trying to infer that anyone should completely avoid using an
> > IDE for development. I was stating that it is not necessary to use an
> > IDE to run a test suite.
>
>
> Understood.
>
> Further, I recommend not using an IDE for running test suites.
>
>
> Why not? You get just as much feedback but on top of that, the IDE will
> take you to failing tests with one press of a key so you can start
> investigating right away...
>
> What do you gain by running the tests from the command line?

Again, I speak of the full unit test suite being run outside of the
IDE. When developing within an IDE by all means use the IDE's unit
test facilities for the classes being worked on at that point.

An example perhaps. When developing in, gasp, Eclipse, I will create
both an object and it's test simultaneously. I will run the test using
Eclipse's JUnit GUI test runner. So, at the object (and it's test)
level, I actually do think you should run the tests inside the IDE.
(Again, this assumes you are an IDE user. Most of the time I am not.)
But, once you are testing at the project level, running suites of
tests, I strongly recommend being outside the IDE. My reasons for this
are many; but the big hitters are that it enables you to run the full
test suite away from the developers and thus avoid disturbing them, it
avoids any dependencies upon libraries on the developers machines and
it enables you to run the builds and tests on a nice big and fast Unix
machine that your IDE of choice may not be available for. We are in
the process of bringing in CruiseControl and will be running it on a
Solaris box. Our corporate IDE (name withheld to protect the lame)
will not run on Solaris, but CC and Ant and JUnit will.

Easy huh?
